abstracts.cdata!:
The Sixth Highway Project only partially
            achieved its main objective of improving communications
            between the Atlantic ports in Barranquilla, Cartagena and
            Santa Marta and the major commercial and industrial centers
            of the country, since nearly half of the intended paving
            works were not completed under the loan. On the other hand,
            construction of the Barranquilla Bridge and completion of
            the Buga-Buenaventura highway were successfully carried out
            under the project and resulted in estimated economic returns
            well above those expected at appraisal. The revised project
            was completed in late 1981, about eight years after the
            original appraisal date. The project completion report (PCR)
            identifies the following reasons for such poor project
            performance: (a) financial difficulties of the Government
            causing tardiness in payment of contractual advances; (b)
            contractors' financial problems stemming from contracts
            based on unrealistically low bids; (c) contractors having
            insufficient equipment; (d) inadequate design plans
            requiring Ministry of Public Works and Transport (MOPT) to
            modify pavements and alignments; (e) lack of experience of
            some field supervision engineers; (f) heavy rains; and (g)
            asphalt shortages.
